citations.narrative:
***There are no completed records of animals on hand available for review. Licensee states the records have not been
updated and she is in the process of working on them. Records shall be maintained that accurately document all
acquisitions, births, deaths and other dispositions as required in the Animal Welfare Regulations, Subpart G section 2.75
(b).
Correct by July 8, 2023.

***The drainage at the entry to the barn for the one enclosure housing the yak and 4 cattle on one side, and the other
enclosure for the pasture animals is not sufficient to rapidly eliminate run-off water. USDA observed large patches of mud
and puddling water retained at the entries to both enclosures. There was no remaining dry entry way to the shelter and
the animals are required to walk through these sections in order to access the shelter.
***The first pen to the right upon approaching the barn, currently referred to as the petting zoo enclosure has standing
puddled water around the water trough for the animals. The enclosure is muddy. Appropriate drainage must be provided
to prevent such accumulations and allow the animals access to their water without requiring them to walk through water
for access.
Extended exposure to mud and muck can lead to problems such as fungal infections, overgrown hoofs, foot rot and
lameness. Appropriate drainage must be provided to allow the animals access to the protection of the shelter while
providing for their health and well-being.
Correct by July 8, 2023.

***Upon entering the barn USDA observed two goats outside of their pen laying in an area where there are chemical
bottles (bleach and aerosol sprays, etc), hay, and trash being stored. Allowing animals to access this area may allow
them to become poisoned or injured. The area shall be blocked off to prohibit access and all chemicals shall be stored in
a manner that will prevent contamination of food and protect the animals from harm.
Correct by July 8, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
